* '''''(Article 179)''''': would be canceled. The article allows the president to use military courts for "terror" cases even for civilians.
* '''''(Article 179)''''': would be canceled. The article allows the president to use military courts for "terror" cases even for civilians.
* '''''(Article 189)''''': Require the newly elected [[Egyptian Parliament|parliament]] to write a new constitution within 60 Days.
* '''''(Article 189)''''': Require the newly elected [[Egyptian Parliament|parliament]] to write a new constitution within 60 Days.
  +   +
==Polls==
  +
A poll done by the Egyptian government on its '''Information and Decision Support Center''' ''(IDSC)'' website said that 24,121 Egyptians (57 percent of the total number of voters) voted against the amendments, while 15,173 Egyptians (37 percent) supported them. Five percent were undecided.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/348851 |title=Majority of Egyptians against constitutional amendments, says poll | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-03-13 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
== Pre-Election Responses ==
== Pre-Election Responses ==
Line 113: Line 116:
The Muslim Brotherhood and the NDP are also perceived to be in favour of a "yes" vote because early elections would benefit them the most, as they have already got a good organization established, while smaller and newly-founded parties would have little time to prepare for elections in the planned schedule.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
The Muslim Brotherhood and the NDP are also perceived to be in favour of a "yes" vote because early elections would benefit them the most, as they have already got a good organization established, while smaller and newly-founded parties would have little time to prepare for elections in the planned schedule.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
